question: What else do you want to know?
answer: Where you're from. I was born in Kentucky, Fort Knox, Kentucky, and I'm an army brat so I'm from all over.

question: When did you come to San Francisco?
answer: We came to San Francisco in '64.

question: Where did you live in San Francisco?
answer: We lived in the Presidio. My father got stationed in Oakland, and we went over to Oakland for six months.

question: Can any of your kids afford the city to buy a home?
answer: I have friends that lived in public housing. The father became a plumber, bought a home, a vacation home in Clear Lake, a vacation home in Bodega, and had a house in South City.

question: What was San Francisco like in the past?
answer: San Francisco used to be a city everybody dreamed of. It was full of union shops, and just about every job in the city was a union job.

question: How can housing be affordable?
answer: The city has to make a policy providing homes for people, not just secured investments for people that have more money than they know what to do with.

question: What about the education system in San Francisco?
answer: You gotta have people that are invested in the school system, want to send their kids to schools, and have an education system that's going to provide them a good education.

question: What was the museum and education system like in the past?
answer: Museums were free, and everything was free. I used to go to the museum in the summer and take classes at the Academy of Sciences.

question: What was the interviewer asking?
answer: this city so it has to be going someplace

question: What was the interviewer asking?
answer: I remember Pacific Heights used to be paved, the streets in Pacifica were paved three times to the one

question: What was the interviewer asking?
answer: They pave it three times to make sure that whoever lived in Pacific I'd say never bought never had to rattle themselves

question: What was the interviewer asking?
answer: I think the commercial areas need to be taken care of and if you've got a 50 million dollar mansion you can afford to pay for your own street if you want it done

question: What was the interviewer asking?
answer: They need to put schools in rich districts so the kid has an idea of what wealth is and what the world is

question: What was the interviewer asking?
answer: When I went to school at Roosevelt, I had friends in Pacific Heights and Presidio Heights

question: What was the interviewer asking?
answer: I got to see what the other half lived like and they got to see how I lived and I think it made for a better education

question: What was the interviewer asking?
answer: You tax speculators

question: What was the interviewer asking?
answer: I think people that don't have any that are just consider housing as investments should get their behind back to the wall

question: What was the interviewer asking?
answer: You want to provide a stable environment for people that are going to teach your kids

question: What was the interviewer asking?
answer: You want all your service workers that work in the city to be able to afford to live here

question: What was the interviewer asking?
answer: You want to disincentivize people from owning huge amounts of real estate or that real estate is an investment

question: What was the interviewer asking?
answer: Maybe you need to get rid of some politicians

question: What was the interviewer asking?
answer: So please correct me if I'm not understanding you

question: What was the interviewer asking?
answer: When you asked that question, is my valuation me considering?

question: What was the interviewer asking?
answer: What was the interviewer asking?

question: What was her comment when she looked around and said 'oh this is nice'?
answer: This is much too nice for poor people.

question: Why did she think it was too nice for poor people?
answer: Poor people live in concrete blocks outside of the city, and that's just where poor people live.

question: What plan did they hatch for San Francisco?
answer: To make San Francisco Manhattan.

question: What did the interviewee think about the idea of converting San Francisco into Manhattan?
answer: It costs like Manhattan, they had no regard for workers.

question: Where did the interviewee suggest people should start thinking more regionally?
answer: In Sam Bruno, South City, Oakland.

question: What did the interviewee think about the idea of building more houses in San Francisco?
answer: It doesn't make sense, it's not affordable because of policies that don't provide for affordability.

question: What did the interviewee suggest as an alternative to building more houses?
answer: To provide good grocery stores, medical buildings, and places for people to get health care and educate themselves.

question: What did the interviewee think about the nature of development in San Francisco?
answer: If you're committed to having families here, you have to start developing as they cost a lot less or the city is going to have to just subsidize them.

question: What did the interviewee suggest for mixed neighborhoods?
answer: People of different finances living side by side, people of different values living side by side.

question: What was the interviewer asking?
answer: Francisco the same thing in San Francisco in general but I think because it was subsidized by the government profit was not the motive and people have to recognize that if they develop that there's no pot of gold at the end of the rainbow.

question: What do they want?
answer: They want a city that has a mixture of people rich and poor, black and white.

question: What services do they want for all?
answer: They also want the services for all, not just rich people who are dissatisfied with not having it their way so they go and create their own services.

question: What do you need to be committed to?
answer: They have to be committed to the idea of San Francisco.

question: Who used to give back to the city?
answer: Rich people used to give back to the city because they got from the city.

question: What do you need to do?
answer: You need a new class of rich people that thinks that's what they need to do, not because it's beneficial for taxes or whatever, but they understand.

question: What was explained to you?
answer: This is what was explained to me, that when they go to the nice little parties, that if you have a bunch of poor people living around you, you don't come back too much in your house.

question: What do you pay insurance for?
answer: In order to pay insurance, you get back to the city because the city has granted you a Wonderful Life.

question: What is part of the insurance?
answer: Part of the insurance is that the people less than you want a wonderful life too.
